p: Despite the large (and mounting) burden imposed by Aedes- and Culex-transmitted viruses [ 1, 2, 4– 13, 23, 24], current mosquito control tactics have often failed to reliably reduce vector:human ratios to values that would keep R 0 below the 1.0 threshold [ 18, 19, 25]. Mosquito control tactics usually combine insecticide spraying to kill adult mosquitoes with the identification and elimination of mosquito breeding sites (i.e., aquatic larval habitats) to limit juvenile mosquito numbers [ 3, 18, 19, 25]. Unfortunately, insecticide spraying has only transient effects on the adult mosquito population, and the proportion of breeding sites that are detected and treated or eliminated (“breeding-site coverage”) is often so low as to render control campaigns largely ineffective (see [ 18, 25]).
